[thus, no global trend in droughts, but an increase in some region and a decrease in others.] hurricanes/tropical cyclones ”there is low confidence in observed long-term trend in hurricane intensity, frequency, and duration, and any observed trend in phenomenon such a tornado and hail.” “data corresponding to hurricane that have directly impacted the united state since 1900 are considered to be reliable, and show no trend in the frequency of u.s. landfall events” “data representing hurricane landfall frequency over australia show a decreasing trend in eastern australia since the 1800s a well a in other part of australia since 1982.” extra tropical storm [ie. major storm outside of the tropics]. “there is overall low confidence in recent change in the total number of storm over both hemispheres” “overall, there is also low confidence in past-century trend in the number and intensity of the strongest storms” so where, in that, is there evidence that "climate change is out of control"? it's interesting and disappointing that the guardian prefers to quote the mis-informed non-expert who doesn't even read his own organisation's report (except of course the summary by policymakers) rather than do it own 'investigative journalism' of actually reading what the 'consensus science' says. it would be the equivalent for the supposed exon scam of 'already knowing about climate change' a if the guardian only quoted the ceo and ignored any other evidence. would they do that? of course not. their action and investigative effort are driven by the agenda they want to present rather than the truth.

carbon dioxide is one of the major gigs and a driver in the domain of climate change. in the drive to mitigate and adapt with the issue of climate change, carbon trading ha become a vital policy instrument in majority of the country in the world. it is also a pivotal element of the unfccc’s approach to tackle climate change. national or regional carbon trading scheme are now operational in many county through a well-defined structural policy, specific for the country. yet the trading is still in a volatile stage. many school think that this concept is not very realistic to combat climate change, while others consider this a strict regulation to put cap/limit on the emitter. unfortunately, the subject is characterised by jargon, abstract concepts, mathematical formulae, and technical detail, making it hard for most people to understand it implication and evaluate it merit and merits. this paper is a first order analysis to unravel some of this complexity by importing thrust on three basic component – cap and trade, carbon offset and carbon trading – which undermine the trade in carbon quotas. the case study of the highly urbanized city of kolkata and indian sundarban mangrove ecosystem ha been discussed in detail with co2 – e of dominant tree to analyse the probable credit that can be received from the producer community of these two site that are significantly different in term of anthropogenic footprint and ecological features. contact abhijit mira

i believe that somehow if we managed to keep the current co2 level stable, that is around 420 ppm or so; the momentum of change we have already made would continue to stabilize the climate to the point where passing several tipping point is inevitable. the death toll from these change will almost certainly amount to about 1/2 of the world population and, even worse, a reduction in the planet's carrying capacity to no more than about 2 billion people. this will transform our current civilization to the point where the standard of living for most individual will crash and kill off 90% of many countries. coupled with the kind of demographic change already occurring in nearly all developed countries, we should expect to see a peak population during the next 10 year followed by a rapid decline. these change are pretty well baked in right now. on the other hand those people predicting the end of the human race because of these change are being silly. the more the population shrinks, the le impact people will have on the environment. unless the planet becomes a snowball earth like that happened several hundred million year ago, there will always be a large area of the planet capable of sustaining a sizeable population. the problem really is that a lot of people will either lose their life or their ability to sustain themselves comfortably. the amount of suffering will be incalculable while the cost of cleaning up the mess becomes unsustainable. by making ludicrous investment today, many, if not most, of these future change can be avoided. that should really be the debate. is it worth a trillion dollar a year to ensure this suffering doesn't occur? we spend that much on making war so the money is available. it seems to me that making our life better should be more important but that is just me.

atmospheric carbon dioxide and aerosol - effect of large increase on global climate abstract. effect on the global temperature of large increase in carbon dioxide and aerosol density in the atmosphere of earth have been computed. it is found that, although the addition of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere doe increase the surface temperature, the rate of temperature increase diminishes with increasing carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. for aerosol, however, the net effect of increase in density is to reduce the surface temperature of earth. because of the exponential dependence of the backscattering, the rate of temperature decrease is augmented with increasing aerosol content. an increase by only a factor of 4 in global aerosol background concentration may be sufficient to reduce the surface temperature by a much a 3.5°k. if sustained over a period of several years, such a temperature decrease over the whole globe is believed to be sufficient to trigger an ice age. s. i. rasool s. h. schneider institute for space studies, goddard space flight center, national aeronautics and space administration, new york 10025.

the truth is, we do not know precisely how much co2 is affecting the atmosphere. there are a lot of feedback both positive and negative. the problem is they change so often that it is impossible to say which is affecting the climate more. take for example, clouds. low level cloud are more transparent to infrared, meaning more escape to space. at the same time, they are more reflective to sunlight. this mean they cause the earth to cool. high level cloud are more reflective of infrared, meaning it cause the earth to stay warm. they also absorb more sunlight meaning it warms the atmosphere during the day. water vapor also trap heat, unlike co2, which release it a fast a it get it in the form of infrared. so when a low energy co2 atom hit a water vapor that ha high energy, it steal some of that energy and release it immediately. water vapor can catch the frequency that co2 emits on, meaning it trap the heat. what this mean is if the majority of cloud are low level we have negative feedback to co2 increases. if the cloud are high, we have positive feedback to co2 increases. the problem is that we have to model the atmosphere at about 1/1000 of what our best computer can do, to figure out the truth. since no computer can handle that, we use model that use a range of a variable called "climate sensitivity to co2 changes". they do the run with the variable at one level, then again at a second level and so on. they often start at .5°c per doubling of co2 and go to 5°c per doubling of co2. the model at the low end are accurate, but can not predict a disaster. the one at the high end do predict a disaster, but after a decade are considerably off. after 2 decade that are way off, and after 3 decades, they are outrageous off. yet they claim the top end is off and we will have a tipping point which switch the sensitivity from the low end to the high, but so far none of these tipping point have done anything.

co2 absorption of terrestrial ir occurs at 15um wavelength and follows "beers law" - college chemistry basics. the absorption is maximize, 99.9%, in under 10m from the earth's surface at co2 concentration of just 200ppm or less. increasing co2 doe not increase absorption further, so there is no increase in ir energy absorption from the earth's surface with co2 doubling. this is basic college chemistry and physics of the issue. the truth is that co2 increase doe not further add to the greenhouse effect than it already does. there is a great series of short 4min lecture on youtube about the detail by michel van been.

ecological grief (or eco-grief), or in particular climate grief, refers to the sense of loss that arises from experiencing or learning about environmental destruction or climate change. environmental grief can be defined a "the grief reaction stemming from the environmental loss of ecosystem by natural and man-made events." another definition is "the grief felt in relation to experienced or anticipated ecological losses, including the loss of species, ecosystems, and meaningful landscape due to acute or chronic environmental change." environmental disruption, such a the loss of biodiversity, or even the loss of inanimate environmental feature like sea ice, cultural landscapes, or historic heritage can also cause negative psychological responses, such a ecological grief or solastalgia. solastalgia (/ˌsɒləˈstældʒə/) is a neologism, formed by the combination of the latin word sōlācum (comfort) and the greek root -alia (pain, suffering, grief), that describes a form of emotional or existential distress caused by environmental change. it is best described a the lived experience of negatively perceived environmental change. a distinction can be made between solastalgia linked to distress about what is in the process of negatively perceived change and eco-anxiety linked to what may happen in the future (associated with "pre-traumatic stress", in reference to post-traumatic stress). eco-anxiety (short for ecological anxiety and also known a eco-distress or climate-anxiety) ha been defined a "a chronic fear of environmental doom". extensive study have been done on ecological anxiety, and various definition remain in use. another widely cited definition is "the generalized sense that the ecological foundation of existence are in the process of collapse." some scholar use the term eco-anxiety a a synonym for climate-anxiety, while others like to treat the term separately. while much ecological disruption result from climate change, some is caused by direct human activity, such a deforestation. the condition is not a medical diagnosis and is regarded a a rational response to the reality of climate change; however, severe instance can have a mental health impact if left without allegation. there is also evidence that eco-anxiety is caused by the way researcher frame their research and their narrative of the evidence about climate change if they do not consider the possibility of finding any solution to overcome climate change and for individual to make a difference, they contribute to this feeling of powerlessness. eco-anxiety is an unpleasant emotion, though it can also motivate useful behavior such a the gathering of relevant information. however, it can also manifest a conflict avoidance, or even be "analyzing". the holocene extinction, or anthropocene extinction, is the ongoing extinction event during the holocene epoch. the extinction span numerous family of plant and animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, invertebrates, and affecting not just terrestrial species but also large sector of marine life. with widespread degradation of biodiversity hotspots, such a coral reef and rainforests, a well a other areas, the vast majority of these extinction are thought to be undocumented, a the species are undiscovered at the time of their extinction, which go unrecorded. the current rate of extinction of species is estimated at hundred to thousand time higher than natural background extinction rates, and is increasing.

artificial intelligence (ai) can play a crucial role in combating climate change by offering innovative solution to regulate temperature and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. here are some example of ai solution that can help regulate temperature in relation to the issue of global warming forecasting and management of renewable energies ai can be used to predict the production of renewable energy such a solar and wind energy, which are inherently intermittent. by using machine learning models, forecast can be improved, enabling better integration of renewable energy source into the power grid. this help balance the supply and demand of electricity, contributing to the regularization of energy consumption. optimization of energy consumption ai can analyze energy consumption pattern in buildings, industries, and cities. by identifying energy efficiencies, ai can recommend adjustment to reduce energy consumption, thereby reducing greenhouse gas emission associated with electricity production. smart agriculture ai can monitor and predict agricultural conditions, such a period of drought or flooding. by identifying optimal time for planting, irritating, or harvesting, farmer can better manage their crop to maintain yield while avoiding excessive water and resource use, helping regulate agricultural ecosystem and mitigate the impact of climate change. advanced climate modeling ai can improve the accuracy of climate model by incorporating a larger amount of data and optimizing model parameters. more accurate climate model help better understand long-term climate trend and identify high-risk area for adaptation measures. monitoring and prevention of natural disasters ai can help monitor extreme weather event such a hurricanes, earthquakes, and floods. by analyzing real-time data, ai can more accurately predict hurricane trajectory or estimate the potential damage caused by a natural disaster. this enables better preparedness, strengthens infrastructure resilience, and save lives. intelligent transportation ai can contribute to improving transport efficiency by optimizing routes, promoting public transportation, and facilitating the adoption of autonomous electric vehicles. more efficient mobility help reduce greenhouse gas emission from the transportation sector. these example demonstrate how the ludicrous use of artificial intelligence can contribute to regulating temperature in the fight against climate change. however, it is essential to note that ai is not a singular solution to the problem of climate change but rather a powerful tool to combine with other efforts, such a adopting effective climate policy and engaging society in the transition to a sustainable economy.

climate change refers to the long-term change in weather pattern that are observed across different region of the earth. these change are primarily driven by human activity that release large amount of greenhouse gases, such a carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere, leading to global warming. the effect of climate change include rising sea levels, melting glacier and ice caps, more frequent and intense heatwaves, droughts, and wildfires, a well a more frequent and severe storm and hurricanes. the scientific consensus is that human activity are the main cause of climate change, and urgent action is needed to mitigate it impact and adapt to it consequences. activity that release large amount of greenhouse gases, such a carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere, leading to global warming. the effect of climate change include rising sea levels, melting glacier and ice caps, more frequent and intense heatwaves, droughts, and wildfires, a well a more frequent and severe storm and hurricanes. the scientific consensus is that human activity are the main cause of climate change, and urgent action is needed to mitigate it impact and adapt to it consequences.

climate change is not "turbocharging weather events". the un's ipcc ar6 report, chapter 11 'weather and climate extreme event in a changing climate' summaries the fact that severe weather event cannot be detected a increasing, nor attributed to human caused climate change increased flooding not detected, no attribution. increased meteorological drought not detected, no attribution. increased hydrological drought not detected, no attribution. increased tropical cyclones not detected, no attribution. increased winter storms not detected, no attribution. increased thunderstorms not detected, no attribution. increased hail not detected, no attribution. increased lightning not detected, no attribution. increased extreme winds not detected, no attribution. there is no climate crisis. the un's ipcc ar6 report, chapter 11 'weather and climate extreme event in a changing climate' summaries the fact that certain severe weather event cannot be detected a increasing, nor attributed to human caused climate change page 1761 - 1765, table 11.a.2 synthesis table summarizing assessment heavy precipitation 24 out of 45 global region low confidence in observed trend (12 medium confidence), 43 out 45 low confidence in human attribution. agricultural drought 31 out of 45 global region low confidence in observed trend (14 medium confidence. no high confidence assessment). 42 out 45 low confidence in human attribution (3 medium, no high confidence). ecological drought a above. hydrological drought 38 out of 45 global region low confidence in observed trend. 43 out 45 low confidence in human attribution (2 medium confidence, no high confidence). so the ipcc are saying we didn't cause drought and we didn't make it rain. how surprising! there is no objective observational evidence that we are living in a global climate crisis. the un's ipcc ar6, chapter 12 "climate change information for regional impact and for risk assessment", section 12.5.2, table 12.12 confirms there is a lack of evidence or no signal that the following have changed air pollution weather (temperature inversions), acidity, avalanche (snow), average precipitation, average wind speed, coastal flood, agricultural drought, hydrological drought, erosion of coastline, fire weather (hot and windy), flooding from heavy rain (plural floods), frost, hail, heavy rain, heavy snowfall and ice storms, landslides, marine heatwaves, ocean acidity, radiation at the earth’s surface, river/lake floods, sand and dust storms, sea level, severe wind storms, snow, glacier, and ice sheets, tropical cyclones. how about some quote from the un's ipcc ar6? "there is low confidence in the emergence of heavy precipitation and plural and river flood frequency in observations, despite trend that have been found in a few regions." "there is low confidence in the emergence of drought frequency in observations, for any type of drought, in all regions." "observed mean surface wind speed trend are present in many areas, but the emergence of these trend from the interannual natural variability and their attribution to human-induced climate change remains of low confidence due to various factor such a change in the type and exposure of recording instruments, and their relation to climate change is not established. . . the same limitation also hold for wind extreme (severe storms, tropical cyclones, sand and dust storms)." there is no objective observational evidence that we are living through a global climate crisis. none.

i am a climate change denier. not because i think we a a human race are incapable of affecting our global climate, (consider the cfc and the hole in the o-zone layer), but because the data on global climate change doe not convince me. it's a simple a that. for instance, in 2006, it wa "global warming," now it's been revised to "global climate change" with an emphasis on increased natural disasters. is global climate change really the cause? or could it simply be that we have greater population in more area around the globe, with more sophisticated equipment to measure our weather? and maybe it just so happened that the earth had a tumultuous few year in the 00's a part of it's natural cycle? i've not been able to find any reliable information to dispute this hypothesis, and i know i'm not the only one whose asked. if the data were convincing, i would be more than happy to support agenda to help restore the earth's natural climate cycle, but a it stands, there are still too many unanswered questions, and not enough data in my view.

a quick warming factor. the unit are zettajoules / year warm the melt the ocean ice glaciation 1.6 1.3 2000-2018 ad 13.7 0.18 "glaciation" is the annual average over 12,500 year of significant sea level rise 20,200 to 7,500 year ago, averaging 10.5 mm / year and always >2.7 mm / year. "2000-2018 ad" is the annual average over 19 year of 2000-2018 ad. one conclusion is that the ocean ha already started warming but the ice hasn't started melting yet. incidentally, the 13.7+0.18=13.88 / year is the precise measure of what's referred to a "climate lag" or "in the pipeline" for future increase of global mean surface temperature (gst) right now.

the lower the ph value, the higher the acidity of a liquid. solution with low ph are acidic and solution with high ph are basic (also known a alkaline). prior to the industrial revolution, average ocean ph wa about 8.2. today, average ocean ph is about 8.1. ph is a measure of how acidic/basic water is. the range go from 0 - 14, with 7 being neutral. ph of le than 7 indicate acidity, whereas a ph of greater than 7 indicates a base. based by this science and a wee bit of simple mathematics (now, i know most of you in the usa will fail to understand this simple mathematical formula a your school test score reveal), show that at the current rate, ocean will become acidic by the year 3400. well past that date if indeed, the polar ice melts.

1. a 15-year-old individual, influenced by climate activist great thunder, approached the narrator at a party with concern about carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere. this person expressed a belief that carbon dioxide constituted over half of the earth's atmosphere and feared suffocation or death from a heatwave before the age of 35. 2. the individual held a conviction that the high level of carbon dioxide wa problematic and that it wa a direct result of the older generations' actions. 3. in an attempt to provide accurate information and perspective, the narrator used a graphical representation similar to those used for covid data to illustrate the proportion of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. 4. the visual representation consisted of a large green square (representing the entire atmosphere) and a much smaller red square (representing carbon dioxide), which showed carbon dioxide a one part of every 2,500 part of the atmosphere. 5. this graphical method faced opposition from some who were surprised or upset by the depiction, linking the reaction to religious offence taken at depiction of sacred figures. 6. the measurement of atmospheric carbon dioxide ha been taken accurately for 60 year at the fauna loa observatory in hawaii, near a volcano. 7. over this 60-year period, carbon dioxide level have increased from 320 part per million (ppm) to 420 ppm, indicating a rise but still showing carbon dioxide a a minor component of the atmosphere, emphasizing it proportion rather than it properties.

dr prof. valentine zharkova so the earth is not warming is cooling!! we have entered the grand solar minimum, and there's no doubt about it. some people have even repeated our findings. kitty ashvily from nasa published a paper in 2020 that echoed our results. they repeated our findings, confirming the same magnetic field changes. nasa ha identified this upcoming solar cycle a the weakest in 200 years, which will likely lead to a global cooling period 2030 to 2100. now, you might wonder why we believe there will be global cooling. let's recall what happened during the grand solar minimum. the irradiance curve from the little ice age, a reproduced by mental, clearly show a drop in solar advance from 1366 to 1363 watt per square meter. this had a significant impact on temperatures, leading to a drop of approximately one degree. similar temperature drop occurred during the dayton minimum. every time there is a prolonged minimum, temperature decrease dramatically. the calculation suggest that we can expect a drop in solar irradiance during the upcoming grand solar minimum. in fact, research by shin delta to one in science support this idea. this drop in temperature ha implication for various regions. some area might experience temperature increases, but northern europe and north america are likely to face significant temperature drops. we could see condition similar to the "deep freeze" that occurred in the past. the drop in temperature is related to a decrease in ozone layer abundance in the atmosphere. this, in turn, affect atmospheric circulation patterns, leading to fluctuation in the northern jet streams. these change allow cold air from the north to propagate towards the south. europe and north america are particularly vulnerable to these shift in the jet streams, which result in colder weather.

i've thought for some time that a major challenge for climate change action is convincing people that change is both necessary and possible. naïve optimism lead people to assume thing will probably be fine, whereas descendant pessimism tell them it's already too late. or short-sighted self-interest can lead some straight from thinking it unnecessary to thinking it impossible change may be in some sense painful (e.g. diminished income or foregoing comforts), so they'd rather believe the problem isn't real. once it becomes impossible to deny the evidence, they pivot to "it's too late anyway, so why should i inconvenience myself in the name of a hopeless effort?" i also wonder to what extent the social and political context we grew up in informs our attitude to this kind of issue. the "end of history" era installed the idea that the big dramatic change were all in the past, and it wa going to be boring technocratic finding from there on out. of course remarkable thing are still achieved - we build ever taller skyscrapers, ever more powerful computer in ever smaller boxes, and so on - but it's all wrapped in the packaging of commerce and commodification. i think many of u struggle to conceive of anything significant being done for a reason other than direct profit. i think that kind of thinking is a trap concerted deliberate effort can effect change. don't give in to despair!

many climate experts, while cautiously welcoming the reference to fossil fuel in the agreement, point to serious weaknesses, including leaving the door open for fossil fuel expansion to continue. harvest singh, the head of global political strategy at nonprofit climate action network international, said “after decade of evasion, cop28 finally cast a glaring spotlight on the real culprit of the climate crisis fossil fuels. a long-overdue direction to move away from coal, oil, and gas ha been set.” but, he added, “the resolution is marred by loophole that offer the fossil fuel industry numerous escape routes, relying on unproven, unsafe technologies.” his reference is to the controversial technology known a carbon capture and storage — a set of technique being developed to pull carbon pollution from polluting facility such a power plant and from the air, and store it underground. the agreement call for an acceleration of the technology. many scientist have expressed concern that carbon capture is unproven at scale, a distraction from policy to cut fossil fuel use and too expensive. some country and expert were alarmed by the agreement’s recognition of a role for “transitional fuels” in the energy transition — largely interpreted to mean natural gas, a planet-heating fossil fuel.

the world agreed to a new climate deal in dubai on wednesday at the cop28 summit after two week of painstaking talks, making an unprecedented call to transition away from fossil fuels, but using vague language that could allow some country to take minimal action. the gave went down on the agreement, known a the global stocktake, in the morning after the talk were pushed into overtime by marathon negotiation between country bitterly divided over the future role for oil, gas and coal.

when it come to fires, global burned area ha decreased by one quarter this century! the world is burning less. for the whole of canada, there is no trend in burn acreage for the period 1980-2021. the previous highest burn acreage wa in 1989. over that same period the trend for number of fire wa slightly downwards (cfb). note that 2020 had the lowest recorded burn acreage and number of fires, so can that record be attributed to man-made climate change? burn acreage wa much, much, higher in the u during the 1920's, 30's and 40's. it peaked in 1930 at well over 50,000,000 acres. the trend is downwards (1926-2020 nic us) eventhough co2 ha increased exponentially. for 2000 onwards the average burn acreage is much le than 10,000,000 acres. the number of fire ha also declined. remember co2 wa increasing all the time. burn area for u in 2023 wa 3rd lowest on record. it wa under 3 million acre well below the ten year average of 7 million and the lowest since 1998 (nic). data for liberia seems harder to come by. however, for the period 1997-2016, the trend wa highly variable (by a factor of 4) but the trend for the annual burn acreage wa downwards (global fire data). for the amazon (2003-2019), 2010 wa the record year for fire emission with all subsequent year lower by at least ½. when it come to wildfire there wa nothing unusual about 2023 summer's fire season in europe (look it up on the offs website). besides all this the forest fire record in southern europe is related to the previous winter rains, not summer temperatures. wetter winter encourage more plant grow, which form more fuel for fire when it dry out. mediterranean summer are always hot and dry enough to allow fire to spread. furthermore, with regard to the ipcc, they have not detected or attributed the number of fire or the burn acreage to man-made climate change. also ipcc only ha medium confidence ( that's a 50-50, so toss a coin) that weather condition that promote wildfire (fire weather) have become more probable in southern europe, northern eurasia, the usa, and australia over the last century. note that annual global wildfire carbon emission have been declining dramatically since 2003, with 2022 being the lowest on record (copernicus). if you took away el niño, a record increase in total solar irradiance, and the tonga eruption (all natural events) there would have been nothing to see in 2023. the tonga eruption injected 142 megatonnes of water vapour into the stratosphere, increasing it water content by 15%. water vapour is a far more powerful greenhouse gas than co2. total solar irradiance satellite data from 1979 onwards show june 2023 at an all time high in over 40 year of measurement (nces.nota). there were low below 1361 w/m² in 2019 to current high over 1362 w/m² in june (using a lowest curve, which also show the fastest rate of increase during this recent period). so we are looking at a change of around 1½ watt over the course of 5 year (the maximum difference is 2.1w/m²). that may not sound much but it exceeds the increase in the earth's energy imbalance (0.9 w/m², 2018 - 1.97 w/m², 2023) (nasa were ebf to). overall the current increase in solar irradiance should give a direct global heating effect of +0.1°c, with an indirect effect of +0.2°c (after schmutz, 2021). this increase in solar irradiance is related to an earlier than expected increase in sunset activity, which ha not yet reached it zenith, and that may not happen for several year (royal observatory belgium), so further heating from this cause can be expected.

i converted a council house a part of cl's detroit for the future in 2015. i installed air source heat pump and solar thermal. there wa some massive problems 1. the heat pump were noisy and bulky. 2. you need to fit a hot water boiler, where if your house is small? 3. the heat when you want it is not responsive a gas heating so you need to plan when you want to be warm. 4. heat pump , ground or air, only work effectively if the property is totally insulated and virtually air tight. i had to fit 100mm thermal insulation to all internal walls. 5. double glazing wasn't effective. i needed triple k glass 6. the control device is complicated and need summer/winter timing program 7. i also fitted solar panels, but the roof wa not new/strong enough to support the panel and needed to be replaced. 8. i wanted ground source heat pump but you need to bury several large coil 10ft into the ground/garden. 9. take up the floor and isolate every joint from the brickwork total cost £143k after 12 month with a tenant the heat pump had to be removed a they couldn't work it properly. all in all it sound a good idea for middle/high income earned but your average tenant in a 1940's semi will never be able to have it.

having worked in the clean energy and renewables space for many years, i’ve seen a lot of misinformation touted in these interviews. renewables are an intermittent source of energy. when comparing the price of renewables to other source like baseload nuclear or fossil fuel energy generators, you need to look at the total system costs. these system cost include the transmission infrastructure needed to transport energy to consumers, and also the enormous amount of storage that’s needed when the renewables aren’t generating anything. if you include the cost of all this extra infrastructure, it is much higher than the cost consumer currently paid for their existing baseload generators. moreover, the area footprint for renewable generation is much larger and conventional based generators. we need to ask ourselves where we’re going to get all the necessary mineral to realise these net zero fantasy by government where are we going to get a cobalt, nickel vanadium, silver?? there aren’t enough known reserve for these mineral at the present time? all these discussion about sustainable aviation, fuel are fanciful. here, again. you need to look at the total system costs, which include harvesting all the biomass and organic resources, transport, cost and refining costs. how much landmark are we going to have to commit for these biomass fuels? and is that the most sustainable outcome for this biomass?

renewable energy, and reaching net zero, currently, there is a lot of effort put into persuading people to buy electric cars, and install heat pumps, while these attempt may be done with the best of intentions, but unfortunately this is the equivalent to putting the (cart before the horse) if everyone switched over in the next few years, the only way we have of supplying enough electricity to power all these devices, would be to pump more natural gas through our gas powered generating plants. i believe that our top priority should be to build much more renewable energy generating capacity, together with energy storage, because energy storage is the key to making any renewable energy system a realistic alternative to fossil fuels. but how much more renewable energy generating capacity do we need? i say 50% more than would be needed on a typical day, so that the surplus can be stored a green chemical energy, probably green hydrogen for day when the sun doe not shine, and the wind doe not blow, but also, a fuel for heavy vehicles, ships, plane and anything else were battery or a cable would not be appropriate. for most of the world, renewable energy will be in the form of solar or wind, but in some place wave or tidal energy would be an option and a few place will have the option of a base load generated by nuclear, but most will need some form of energy storage, lucky there is a huge range of option trying to get your attention, from a variety of battery types, from sodium-ion or sulphur variants, redox flow batteries, nickel hydrogen, to dome filled with co2 a part of a compressed gas system, but not lithium-ion batteries, which keep getting more expensive due to rarity of the material they are made from, plus, there is environmental damage caused by the mining and processing of these materials, then there are the slightly unusual option employing the raising and lowering of weight to store energy. then there is long-term storage, for when the wind and the sun don’t play ball for day or even week at a time. every winter the u.k. is subject to meteorological weather events, known a a blocking high pressure system, which can last for up to two week at a time, and they usually come complete with a blanket of cloud, which further reduces an already limited amount of light for solar panels, plus there is little, or no wind for the wind turbines, leaving u with just nuclear power stations, that supply only 30% of our energy needs, which will go nowhere near meeting our energy demands, put simply we need a system that can store and supply between 60 to 70% of our energy need for up to a month each winter, only a chemical storage system, such a green hydrogen would have the capacity to storage energy for such a period, if we are not to fall back onto fossil fuels. it ha been suggested that large scale energy storage is unnecessary, and that we should rely on interconnectors under the sea to transfer electricity backwards and forward between ourselves and europe, on the assumption that some part of europe will always have a surplus we can use, but i can see a scenario where eastern europe is suffering a winter cold snap and need all the energy it can get, britain and the low country are stuck under a blocking high pressure system, so no wind, plus spain and portugal are covered by rain bearing cloud, so minimal solar power, and such a situation would not be that unusual, and given recent development with the war in ukraine to satisfy a small man’s ego, it would be extremely unwise to assume that our partner in europe will always be willing, or even able to supply u with what we want, when we want it, generating and storing our own surplus energy, mean we stay in control. interconnectors under the sea would be nice to have but should not be relied upon. another idea doing the rounds, say we build the bare minimum amount of renewable capacity, and use smart technology to switch on or off an internet of things, a a way of balancing supply and demand, where large tech company would control the operation of everything from large factories, to your domestic washing machine or fridge, i believe this is a distraction, i believe that the big technology company could build such a smart system, but i also believe that the tech company already have too much control over our lives, and i believe our goal should be to build 50% more renewable capacity than we need, so the excess can be stored, and we do not have to rely on a smart system that could be hacked.

the amount of hydrogen needed to replace a conventional power plant depends on several factors, including the power plant's capacity, efficiency, and the energy content of hydrogen. 1. **power plant capacityKiss* consider the capacity of the conventional power plant you want to replace. power plant are often rated in term of megawatts (mw) or megawatts (gw). 2. **efficiency of hydrogen conversionKiss* hydrogen can be used in different way to generate electricity, such a through hydrogen fuel cell or hydrogen combustion. the efficiency of these process can vary. 3. **energy content of hydrogenKiss* hydrogen ha an energy content usually measured in megajoules per kilogram (mj/kg) or gigajoules per kilogram (gj/kg), depending on the unit of measurement. once you have these parameters, you can calculate the amount of hydrogen needed using the following general formula \[ \text{hydrogen needed (in kg)} = \frac{\text{electricity needed (in mw)}}{\text{efficiency of hydrogen conversion}} \times \frac{1}{\text{energy content of hydrogen (in mj or gj per kg)}} \] this calculation provides an estimate of the mass of hydrogen required to generate a certain amount of electricity with a specific efficiency. it's important to note that transitioning from a conventional power plant to a hydrogen-based system involves various technical, economic, and infrastructure considerations. hydrogen production, storage, and distribution infrastructure need to be developed, and the overall feasibility depends on the specific context and goal of the energy transition. smiling face with smiling eyes smiling face with smiling eyes smiling face with smiling eyes chatgpt!!!!

with no due respect, the population splitting into different group is not helping, here's why a planet for the 99%” draw on research by the stockholm environment institute (sei) and ass the consumption emission of different income group in 2019, the most recent year for which data are available. the report show the stark gap between the carbon footprint of the super-rich —whose carbon-hungry lifestyle and investment in polluting industry like fossil fuel are driving global warming— and the bulk of people across the world. the richest 1 percent (77 million people) were responsible for 16 percent of global consumption emission in 2019 —more than all car and road transport emissions. the richest 10 percent accounted for half (50 percent) of emissions. it would take about 1,500 year for someone in the bottom 99 percent to produce a much carbon a the richest billionaire do in a year. every year, the emission of the richest 1 percent cancel out the carbon saving coming from nearly one million wind turbines. since the 1990s, the richest 1 percent have used up twice a much of the carbon we have left to burn without increasing global temperature above the safe limit of 1.5°c than the poorest half of humanity. the carbon emission of richest 1 percent are set to be 22 time greater than the level compatible with the 1.5°c goal of the paris agreement in 2030.

most people, including many greenpeace members, activist like great etc, don't understand two important points. 1. global warming equal *change.* flood where previously have been no floods, draught where previously were rivers, ocean where previously wa land and dry river bed where previously were mountain glaciers. it is the *change* that will make hundred of million lose their homes, suffer and migrate. for thousand of year human settlement distribution were influenced by natural conditions. those condition now change *rapidly* and *suddenly.* this is the biggest problem, not the global rise in temperature itself, but the rapidness of the change + the secondary problem it will create (unprecedented migration, crises, tensions, wars, maybe even fall of western democratic world) 2. when we finally shift from the need to explain global warming to denier and their creator (politicians) to the debate how to actually solve the problem, there will be first many error and faults. the pioneer in the process of transformation to sustainable energy (america, europe, partly asia) will make those. we have been already witness to some. like the electricity car fashion blunder, or the pushed and unprepared german energy switch from nuclear to solar/wind without thinking of the consequence (war in ukraine being one such consequence). thus, some of the intended climate "reliefs" will be in fact climate burdens. thus, the second point is, that we are still only learning how to transform to sustainable energy. if the most developed country in the world struggle with it, imagine how third world will.

there are many wonderful benefit that forest bring, and there are many good reason to plant forest and prevent deforestation. forest help remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, and that help in the fight against climate change. but…forests cannot stop climate change from happening. forest are part of the carbon cycle they take in carbon from the atmosphere and store it in the wood. when tree die, the wood is decomposed and the carbon return to the atmosphere. it’s a natural cycle that’s been running for hundred of million of years. the issue is with fossil fuels. fossil fuel take carbon from deep underground and inject them into the carbon cycle, causing an imbalance. forest help, but to truly stop human-induced climate change, we need to leave the fossil fuel in the ground.

nice video, some would say too little, too late, but i would say it doe not work like this. people don't understand, including "scientists", that these attempt are mockery of natural systems. a forest is a pinnacle of vegetation's succession. a system that includes not just tree of various species and age, but all other life form in soil and above it. it also includes different layer of canopy, shrubs and vines, fungus etc. all working together; in relation to water cycle and climate types. natural forest are dynamic system which have been accumulating fertility for centuries. you can't just plant some tree in a clear-cut field or a degraded, former monocrop toxic wasteland and expect a success, let alone expect to have a function of a forest. usually these "forests" are evenly spaced row of young tree of the same species, never pioneering species, planted into sterile and dry dirt, susceptible to all kind of pests... nature doesn't work like this, it work through the succession. this is why very few of these tree live long enough, they are dying because the functional support element are missing. not to mention broken water cycles...and lack of life diversity. thinking only in term of co2 concentration is going to be our downfall.

the solution is to requester all the carbon that we have released in the stock of living biomass (as it is presently accumulating in the atmosphere and in the ocean precisely because we are not doing so). however, conservation/preservation, a currently practiced, is not the answer for two reasons first, it doe nothing to change the lifestyle of most humans. you can’t have conservation here and business a usual everywhere else. everything is connected to everything so unless we remove polluting, habitat destructive & appropriation industry and human activity from the surface of the planet (and preferably place them in outer space) and simultaneously create an ecologically literate population and an ecological-based and ecologically-constrained technology and economy, what little good conservation effort produce will be of little help. conservation make people feel good to think that some “wild” area are being preserved. but this is simply untrue and promoting this lie a true is thus counterproductive. second, what we currently view and seek to conserve a “pristine wilderness” is actually highly degraded land that wa slowly recovering from the extinction associated with pleistocene climate change and wa then set back and made substantially worse by the process and demand of agricultural and industrial human civilization. thus ecological restoration and enhancement of ecosystem to pre-pleistocene universities, abundance and functional capacities, rather than preservation of degraded ecosystems, ought to be the goal. furthermore, the gene of the descendant of species that lived during the warmer period of the scene are a key part of the solution. they should be closely examined and sequenced a gene may be found that can help wild species to adapt to a rapidly warming climate. wild species (and in many area domesticated livestock) cannot simply run into an air conditioned space to ride out an area-wide heat wave. without habitat enhancement, migration corridor and migration assistance and likely genetic engineering, death and further extinction and ecosystem collapse are likely if not inevitable outcomes.

it's hard to care, because there's nothing to care about. globally the ace index (accumulated cyclone energy) 1980-2021 show no increasing trend. global hurricane landfall 1970-2021 (updated from twinkle et al, 2012) show no trend. satellite data since 1980 show a slight downward global trend for total hurricane number with 2021 being a record low year. the ipcc report in ar6, chapter 11, "the total global frequency of tc [tropical cyclone] formation will decrease or remain unchanged with increasing global warming (medium confidence)." not that i really care about what the ipcc says. multidecadal variability in atlantic hurricanes is most probably related to the amo (hacchi et al, 2021). nota data 1851-2021 show no trend in number of hurricane landfall with the record high being 1886. what the data from nota spc show about tornado ef1-ef5 (1954-2022) no trend; ef3-ef5 (most destructive) (1954-2022) 50% decline. no ef5s in u since 2013 (a record absence). the global land precipitation anomaly from ar5 will disappoint with deviation from the average increasing by 0.2% per decade, but if you look at the actual data, it's just very variable over the decades. drought appears to be decreasing globally (watts et al, 2018) measured by spi 1901-2017. for every million people on earth, annual death from climate-related cause (extreme temperature, drought, flood, storms, wildfires) declined 98%--from an average of 247 per year during the 1920s to 2.5 in per year during the 2010s. data on disaster death come from (em-dat, red / uclouvain, brussels,belgium. ) globally 2000-2019 there wa a large decrease in cold-related death and a moderate increase in heat-related death (hao, 2021, lancet). however, coldwaves are over 9 time more likely to kill than heatwaves, so the overall result is very beneficial. what else? oh, desert like the share have shrunk considerably and the earth ha greeted by 15% or more in a human lifetime (nasa). the great barrier reef's coral cover ha reached the greatest extent ever recorded. on extinction the rate is very low 900 known lost species for 2.1 million known species in 500 years. at that frequency it will take over 930,000 year to reach 80% extinction of species experienced at the k-t boundary that saw the extinction of the dinosaurs. there is no climate crisis.

i just asked chatgpt about current co2 concentration and the minimum concentration required for plants. it's pretty much in line what the guy said and absolutely devastating for the anti-co2 agenda. i haven't wondered yet about a minimum a of my last update, which wa in january 2022, carbon dioxide (co2) comprises about 0.0415% of earth's atmosphere by volume. however, this percentage can vary slightly depending on location, altitude, and other factors. plant generally require a minimum concentration of co2 for photosynthesis to occur efficiently. this threshold concentration is typically around 150 part per million (ppm). however, most plant prefer higher concentrations, ideally between 300 and 400 ppm. co2 is a crucial component of photosynthesis, a plant use it along with water and light energy to produce sugar and oxygen. without an adequate supply of co2, plant growth and productivity can be limited.

history the 2030 agenda for sustainable development, adopted by all united nation member state in 2015, provides a shared blueprint for peace and prosperity for people and the planet, now and into the future. at it heart are the 17 sustainable development goal (sds), which are an urgent call for action by all country - developed and developing - in a global partnership. they recognize that ending poverty and other deprivation must go hand-in-hand with strategy that improve health and education, reduce inequality, and spur economic growth – all while tackling climate change and working to preserve our ocean and forests. the sds build on decade of work by country and the un, including the un department of economic and social affair in june 1992, at the earth summit in rio de janeiro, brazil, more than 178 country adopted agenda 21, a comprehensive plan of action to build a global partnership for sustainable development to improve human life and protect the environment. member state unanimously adopted the millennium declaration at the millennium summit in september 2000 at un headquarters in new york. the summit led to the elaboration of eight millennium development goal (mds) to reduce extreme poverty by 2015. the johannesburg declaration on sustainable development and the plan of implementation, adopted at the world summit on sustainable development in south africa in 2002, reaffirmed the global community's commitment to poverty eradication and the environment, and built on agenda 21 and the millennium declaration by including more emphasis on multilateral partnerships. at the united nation conference on sustainable development (rio+20) in rio de janeiro, brazil, in june 2012, member state adopted the outcome document "the future we want" in which they decided, inter alia, to launch a process to develop a set of sds to build upon the mds and to establish the un high-level political forum on sustainable development. the rio +20 outcome also contained other measure for implementing sustainable development, including mandate for future programme of work in development financing, small island developing state and more. in 2013, the general assembly set up a 30-member open working group to develop a proposal on the sds. in january 2015, the general assembly began the negotiation process on the post-2015 development agenda. the process culminated in the subsequent adoption of the 2030 agenda for sustainable development, with 17 sds at it core, at the un sustainable development summit in september 2015. 2015 wa a landmark year for multilateralism and international policy shaping, with the adoption of several major agreements send framework for disaster risk reduction (march 2015) adds baba action agenda on financing for development (july 2015) transforming our world the 2030 agenda for sustainable development with it 17 sds wa adopted at the un sustainable development summit in new york in september 2015. paris agreement on climate change (december 2015) now, the annual high-level political forum on sustainable development self a the central un platform for the follow-up and review of the sds. today, the division for sustainable development goal (did) in the united nation department of economic and social affair (under) provides substantive support and capacity-building for the sds and their related thematic issues, including water, energy, climate, oceans, urbanization, transport, science and technology, the global sustainable development report (user), partnership and small island developing states. did play a key role in the evaluation of un systemwide implementation of the 2030 agenda and on advocacy and outreach activity relating to the sds. in order to make the 2030 agenda a reality, broad ownership of the sds must translate into a strong commitment by all stakeholder to implement the global goals. did aim to help facilitate this engagement. follow did on facebook at and on twitter at @sustdev.
